revision.comment: upper case (Moon, per proper name and Wikipedia style)
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Arianespace | logo = Arianespace logo.svg | type = [[Launch Service Provider]] | founded = 1980 | founder = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = [[Aerospace]] | genre = | products = | services = Rocket Launches | revenue = {{increase}} [[euro|€]]1.433 billion (2015) | operating_income = | net_income = {{increase}} [[euro|€]]4 million (2015) | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 321<ref name="2014annualreport">{{cite report|title=2014 Annual Report |url=http://www.arianespace.com/about-us-corporate-information/Annual-Report-2014-EN.pdf |publisher=Arianespace |date=15 June 2015 |location=Courcouronnes, France |accessdate=6 August 2015 |format=PDF}}</ref> | parent = [[ArianeGroup]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [http://www.arianespace.com arianespace.com] | footnotes = | intl = | location_city = [[Courcouronnes]] | location_country = [[France]] | location = | locations = | caption = }}
'''Arianespace SA''' is a [[multinational company]] founded in 1980 as the world's first commercial [[launch service provider]].<ref name=Jaeger1986/> It undertakes the operation and marketing of the [[Ariane (rocket family)|Ariane]] programme.<ref name=arianespace1980/> The company offers a number of different [[launch vehicle]]s: the [[heavy-lift launch vehicle|heavy-lift]] [[Ariane 5]] for dual launches to [[geostationary transfer orbit]], the [[Soyuz-2]] as a [[medium-lift launch vehicle|medium-lift]] alternative, and the [[solid-fuel rocket|solid-fueled]] [[Vega (rocket)|Vega]] for lighter payloads.<ref name="launchers">{{cite web|title= Service & Solutions|url=http://www.arianespace.com/about-us/service-solutions.asp|publisher=arianespace.com|accessdate=2011-02-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110212040834/http://arianespace.com/about-us/service-solutions.asp| archivedate= 12 February 2011 <!--DASHBot-->|url-status = live}}</ref>
{{As of|2017|5}}, Arianespace had launched more than 550 satellites<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arianespace.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Company-profile-May-2017.pdf |title=Arianespace company profile |publisher=Arianespace |date=May 5, 2017 |access-date=May 23, 2017}}</ref> in 254 launches over {{age|1984|5|23}} years (236 Ariane missions minus the first 8 flights handled by [[CNES]], 17 Soyuz-2 missions and 9 Vega missions). The first commercial flight managed by the new entity was [[Spacenet F1]] launched on 23 May 1984. Arianespace uses the [[Guiana Space Center]] in [[French Guiana]] as its main launch site. Through shareholding in [[Starsem]], it can also offer commercial Soyuz launches from the [[Baikonur spaceport]] in Kazakhstan. It has its headquarters in [[Courcouronnes]], [[Essonne]], [[France]],<ref>"[http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-9095324_ITM Russians, French sign space contract.(UPI Science Report)]." ''[[United Press International]]''. 12 April 2005. Retrieved on 24 September 2009.</ref> near [[Évry, Essonne|Évry]].<ref>"[http://www.arianespace.com/about-us/contact-us.asp Contact us]." Arianespace. Retrieved on 24 September 2009.</ref>
== History ==
Arianespace SA was founded in 1980 as the operation and marketing arm of the [[Ariane (rocket family)|Ariane launch vehicle]] programme,<ref name=Jaeger1986> {{Cite conference |conference=Proceedings of the 15th International Symposium on Space Technology and Science |location=Tokyo, Japan |date=May 1986 |title=Ariane — The first commercial space transportation system |bibcode=1986spte.conf.1431J |publisher=AGNE Publishing, Inc. |publication-date=1986 |volume=2 |id=A87-32276 13-12 |author1=Jaeger, Ralph-W. |author2=Claudon, Jean-Louis }}</ref><ref name=arianespace1980> {{cite web |title=Arianespace was founded in 1980 as the world’s first launch services company |url=http://www.arianespace.com/site/about/arianespace_today_sub_index.html |publisher=arianespace.com |accessdate=2008-03-07 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218002917/http://www.arianespace.com/site/about/arianespace_today_sub_index.html |archivedate=February 18, 2008}}</ref> seven years after the formation of the pan-national Ariane programme by the [[European Space Agency]] in 1973.<ref name=harvey2003>{{cite book |last=Harvey|first1=Brian |title=Europe's Space Programme: To Ariane and Beyond |publisher=Springer Science & Business Media |year=2003 |isbn=1-8523-3722-2 |accessdate= }}</ref>{{rp|161}} The launcher was to be developed for the purpose of sending [[Commercial use of space#Satellites and equipment|commercial satellites]] into [[geosynchronous orbit]] with a family of Ariane [[launch vehicle]]s.<ref name=harvey2003/>{{rp|161–166}} [[Government of France|France]] was the largest stakeholder in the Ariane [[new product development|development]] programme.<ref name=harvey2003/>{{rp|166}}
Immediately following the successful [[maiden flight|first test launch]] of an [[Ariane 1]] on 24 December 1979, The French space agency [[CNES]] and ESA created a new company—''Arianespace''—for the purpose of promoting, marketing, and managing Ariane operations.<ref name=harvey2003/>{{rp|169}} Three addition test flights were carried out, with one failure and two more successes. The first commercial launch took place on 10 September 1982, and ended in failure when a [[turbopump]] failed in the third stage.<ref name=harvey2003/>{{rp|170–172}} The six remaining flights of Ariane 1 were successful, with the final flight occurring in February 1986.
On 21 October 2011 Arianespace [[Soyuz at the Guiana Space Centre#Inaugural flight|launched the first Soyuz rocket]] ever from outside former [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] territory. The payload consisted of two [[Galileo (satellite navigation)|Galileo]] navigation satellites.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://interspacenews.com/tabid/130/Arianespace_Launches_First_European_Soyuz.aspx?id=7475 |title=Arianespace Launches First European Soyuz |publisher=Interspacenews.com |accessdate=2011-12-17}}</ref>
On 21 January 2019, ArianeGroup and Arianespace announced that it had signed a one-year contract with the [[European Space Agency|ESA]] to study and prepare for a mission to the Moon to mine [[regolith]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2019/01/23/mining-on-the-moon-could-be-a-reality-as-early-as-2025/|title=Mining on the moon could be a reality as early as 2025|last=Wehner|first=Mike|date=23 January 2019|website=New York Post|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=23 January 2019}}</ref>
== Company and infrastructure ==
[[Image:250px-Arianespace logo svg.png|right|thumb|Arianespace Logo from 2009-2017]] Arianespace "is the marketing and sales organization for the European space industry and various component suppliers."<ref name=CASBAA2013> {{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XZ-7nNw-04Q&t=1745 |people=Mr. Richard<!-- moderator introduced as "Richard, representing Arianespace" --> |title=Singapore Satellite Industry Forum 2013 - Changing the Launch Game? |date=23 June 2013 |medium=video |location=Singapore Satellite Industry Forum 2013 |at=29:05 |publisher=[[CASBAA|Cable and Satellite Broadcasting Association of Asia]] |via=YouTube |accessdate=14 April 2018 }}</ref>
The primary shareholders of Arianespace are its [[Supply (economics)|suppliers]],{{why|date=September 2019}}<!-- the Wikipedia article would be improved if we could explain why it is owned by its suppliers with a good source on how this came about. --> in various European nations.<ref name=sn20141120> {{cite news |last1=de Selding|first1=Peter B. |title=Europe’s Satellite Operators Urge Swift Development of Ariane 6 |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/42610europe%E2%80%99s-satellite-operators-urge-swift-development-of-ariane-6 |accessdate=2014-11-21 |work=SpaceNews |date=2014-11-20 |quote=''France-based Arianespace has responded by squeezing, to a limited degree, its supplier base. But Ariane 5 builders are also Arianespace shareholders, limiting the company’s leverage on them.'' }}</ref> Arianespace had 24 shareholders in 2008,<ref name=shareholders200809>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080918045636/http://www.arianespace.com/about-us-corporate-information/shareholders.asp Corporate information > Shareholders], Arianespace, 8 September 2008, accessed 16 April 2008.</ref> 21 in 2014,<ref name="shareholders201410"> {{cite web |url=http://www.arianespace.com/about-us-corporate-information/shareholders.asp |title=Shareholders |publisher=Arianespace |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008022811/http://www.arianespace.com/about-us-corporate-information/shareholders.asp |url-status = dead|archivedate=8 October 2014 |accessdate=14 April 2018 }}</ref> and just 17 {{as of|October 2018|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arianespace.com/company-profile/ |title=Company profile – Repartition of Arianespace capital |publisher=Arianespace |access-date=25 October 2018}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- !scope="col"|Country !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"|Total share !scope="col"|Shareholder !scope="col" data-sort-type="number"|Capital |- | rowspan="3" | {{BEL}} | rowspan="3" | 3.36% | [[SABCA]] | 2.71% |- | [[Thales Alenia Space]] Belgium | 0.33% |- | {{Interlanguage link|Safran Aero Boosters|fr}} | 0.32% |- | rowspan="5" | {{FRA}} | rowspan="5" | 64.10% |- | [[ArianeGroup]] | 62.10% |- | [[Air Liquide]] SA | 1.89% |- | {{Interlanguage link|Clemessy|fr}} | 0.11% |- | CIE Deutsche | <0.01% |- | rowspan="2" | {{GER}} | rowspan="2" | 19.85% | [[ArianeGroup]] | 11.59% |- | {{Interlanguage link|MT Aerospace|de}} AG | 8.26% |- | {{ITA}} | 3.38% | [[Avio]] S.p.A. | 3.38% |- | {{NLD}} | 1.94% | [[Airbus Defence and Space]] B.V. | 1.94% |- | {{NOR}} | 0.11% | [[Kongsberg Defence & Aerospace]] AS | 0.11% |- | rowspan="2" | {{ESP}} | rowspan="2" | 2.14% | [[Airbus Defence and Space]] SAU | 2.03% |- | [[CRISA]] | 0.11% |- | rowspan="2" | {{SWE}} | rowspan="2" | 2.45% | [[GKN Aerospace]] Sweden AB | 1.63% |- | [[RUAG Space]] AB | 0.82% |- | {{CHE}} | 2.67% | [[RUAG Space#Company structure and sites|RUAG Schweiz]] AG | 2.67% |}
In 2015, Arianespace shareholding was restructured due to the creation of [[Airbus Safran Launchers]] (later renamed ArianeGroup), which is tasked with developing and manufacturing the [[Ariane 6]] carrier rocket. Industrial groups [[Airbus]] and [[Safran]] pooled their shares along with the French government's [[CNES]] stake to form a partnership company holding just under 74% of Arianespace shares, while the remaining 26% is spread across suppliers in nine countries including further Airbus subsidiaries.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2015/06/10/le-gouvernement-privatise-arianespace_4650837_3234.html |title=Le gouvernement privatise Arianespace |language=fr |trans-title=Government privatizes Arianespace |newspaper=[[Le Monde]] |first=Dominique |last=Gallois |date=10 June 2015 |access-date=25 October 2018}}</ref>
===Corporate management=== {{As of|October 2018}}, the Arianespace management team was:<ref name="management201409">{{cite web |url=http://www.arianespace.com/governance/ |title=Governance |publisher=Arianespace |date=2018 |access-date=25 October 2018}}</ref> {| class="wikitable" ! Position ! Name |- | Arianespace Chief Executive Officer, ArianeGroup Executive VP | {{Interlanguage link|Stéphane Israël|fr}} |- | Senior Vice-President, Sales & Business Development | Jacques Breton |- | Senior Vice-President, Missions, Operations & Purchasing | Luce Fabreguettes |- | Senior Vice President – Technical and Quality; Chief Technical Officer | Roland Lagier |- | Senior Vice President, Chief Financial Officer | Michel Doubovick |- | Senior Vice President, Human Resources | Philippe Nicolaï |- | Senior Vice President, Brand and Communications | Isabelle Veillon |}
==== Regional offices ==== {| class="wikitable" ! Location ! Head of branch |- | French Guiana | Bruno Gérard |- | USA, Washington D.C. | Wiener Kernisan |- | Japan, Tokyo | Kiyoshi Takamatsu |- | [[ASEAN]], Singapore | Vivian Quenet |}
===Subsidiaries=== * Arianespace inc. (U.S. Subsidiary) * Arianespace Singapore PTE LTD. (Asian Subsidiary) * [[Starsem]] S.A. (European-Russian Soyuz commercialization)
==Competition and pricing== {{main|Space launch market competition}}
In 2004, Arianespace held more than 50% of the world market for boosting satellites to [[geostationary transfer orbit]] (GTO).<ref>{{cite book|title=The European Union|author=John McCormick|pages=[https://archive.org/details/europeanunionpol0000mcco_d3k0/page/273 273]|publisher=[[Westview Press]]|edition=3rd|isbn=978-0-8133-4202-3|date=2004|url=https://archive.org/details/europeanunionpol0000mcco_d3k0/page/273}}</ref>
However, the disruptive force represented by the new sector entrant [[SpaceX]] forced Arianespace to cut back on its workforce and focus on cost-cutting to decrease costs to remain competitive against the new low-cost entrant in the launch sector.
According to an Arianespace managing director, "It's quite clear there's a very significant challenge coming from [[SpaceX]]," he said in 2015. "Therefore things have to change … and the whole European industry is being restructured, consolidated, rationalised and streamlined."<ref name=SMH-2015-05-19>{{cite news |url= http://www.smh.com.au/business/nbn-launcher-arianespace-to-cut-jobs-and-costs-to-fight-spacex-20150519-gh4i4x.html |title= NBN launcher Arianespace to cut jobs and costs to fight SpaceX |date= 19 May 2015 |author= David Ramli |publisher= The Sydney Morning Herald (Australia) }}</ref>
In the midst of [[competition (economics)|pricing pressure]] from U.S. company [[SpaceX]], Arianespace made a November 2013 announcement of pricing flexibility for the "lighter satellites" it carries to [[Geostationary transfer orbit|Geostationary]] orbits aboard its Ariane 5.<ref name=CASBAA2013/><ref name=sn20131125> {{cite news |last=de Selding|first=Peter B. |title=SpaceX Challenge Has Arianespace Rethinking Pricing Policies |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/38331spacex-challenge-has-arianespace-rethinking-pricing-policies |accessdate=2013-11-27 |newspaper=Space News |date=2013-11-25 |quote=''The Arianespace commercial launch consortium is telling its customers it is open to reducing the cost of flights for lighter satellites on the Ariane 5 rocket in response to the challenge posed by SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket.''}}</ref>
In early 2014, Arianespace was considering requesting additional subsidies from European governments to face the competition from SpaceX and unfavorable changes in the Euro-Dollar exchange rate. The company had halved subsidy support by €100m per year since 2002 but the fall in the value of the US Dollar meant Arianespace was losing €60m per year due to currency fluctuations on launch contracts.<ref name=aw20140211>{{cite news |last=Svitak|first=Amy |title=Arianespace To ESA: We Need Help |url=http://www.aviationweek.com/Article.aspx?id=/article-xml/awx_02_11_2014_p0-663010.xml |accessdate=2014-02-12 |newspaper=Aviation Week |date=2014-02-11 }}</ref>
Reducing the cost allowed Arianespace to sign four additional contracts in September 2014 for lower slots on an [[Ariane 5 SYLDA]] dispenser for the satellites that otherwise could be flown on a SpaceX launch vehicle.
Arianespace signed 11 contracts in 2014 until September that year. with two additional being in a late stage of negotiations. {{As of|2014|September}} Arianespace has a backlog of launches worth {{Euro|4.5}} billion with 38 satellites to be launched on [[Ariane 5]], 7 on [[Soyuz at the Guiana Space Centre|Soyuz]] and 9 on [[Vega (rocket)|Vega]], claiming 60% of the global satellite launch market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n1409/08ariane5contracts/|title=Arianespace nets four commercial launch contracts|date=8 September 2014|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2014/9-8-2014-Euroconsult2014.asp|title=World Satellite Business Week 2014: A rich harvest of contracts for Arianespace|date=8 September 2014|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexknapp/2014/09/08/europes-arianespace-claims-60-of-the-commercial-launch-market/|title=Europe's Arianespace Claims 60% Of The Commercial Launch Market|date=9 September 2014|accessdate=9 September 2014}}</ref>
By November 2014, SpaceX had "already begun to take market share"<ref name=sn20141120/> from Arianespace, and [[Eutelsat]] CEO [[Michel de Rosen]] — a major customer of Arianespace — said that "Each year that passes will see SpaceX advance, gain market share and further reduce its costs through [[economies of scale]]."<ref name=sn20141120/>
== Launch vehicles == [[File:Arianespace mockups (37108595462).jpg|thumb|Mockups of all the launch vehicles that Arianespace markets as of 2017: Vega, Vega-C, Soyuz, Ariane 5, and the future Ariane 6.]] Currently Arianespace operates 3 launch vehicles, including two versions of Ariane 5: {| class="wikitable sortable" |- !scope="col"|Name !scope="col"|Payload to [[Low Earth orbit|LEO]] (including [[Sun-synchronous orbit|SSO]]) !scope="col"|Payload to [[Geostationary transfer orbit|GTO]] |- | [[Vega (rocket)|Vega]] | {{convert|1450|kg}} | - |- | [[Soyuz at the Guiana Space Centre|Soyuz]] | {{convert|4400|kg}} | {{convert|3250|kg}} |- | [[Ariane 5]] ECA | - | {{convert|10500|kg}} |- | [[Ariane 5]] ES | {{convert|21000|kg}} | - |} Additionally Arianespace offers optional back-up launch service on [[H-IIA]] through [[Launch Services Alliance]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2013/6-7-2013-MHI.asp|title=Mitsubishi Heavy Industries and Arianespace conclude MOU on cooperation in commercial space rocket launches|publisher=Arianespace|date=7 June 2013|accessdate=18 August 2014}}</ref>
===Ariane launch vehicles=== {{Main|Ariane (rocket family)}} Since the first launch in 1979, there have been several versions of the Ariane [[launch vehicle]]:
* [[Ariane 1]], first successful launch on December 24, 1979 * [[Ariane 2]], first successful launch on November 20, 1987 ''(the first launch on May 30, 1986 failed)'' * [[Ariane 3]], first successful launch on August 4, 1984 * [[Ariane 4]], first successful launch on June 15, 1988 * [[Ariane 5]], first successful launch on October 30, 1997 ''(the first launch on June 4, 1996 failed)''. The new [[Ariane 6]] vehicle is in development. It would have a similar payload capacity to the Ariane 5 but have considerably lower costs. Tentatively, its first flight is planned for 2020.
==See also== {{Portal| Spaceflight |France|Companies}} * [[Europa rocket]] * [[NewSpace]]
